batch.name: Class 12 - Chapter 8: Human Health and Disease

questions.question: The pathogen of typhoid fever is:
questions.explanation: Typhoid fever is caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi, which enters the small intestine through contaminated food and water and migrates to other organs through blood.

questions.question: Widal test is used for the confirmation of which disease?
questions.explanation: Widal test is a serological test used for the diagnosis and confirmation of typhoid fever. It detects antibodies against Salmonella typhi in the patient's serum.

questions.question: Which of the following is the vector for malaria?
questions.explanation: Malaria is transmitted by the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. The female mosquito requires a blood meal for egg development and serves as the vector for Plasmodium parasites.

questions.question: The infective stage of Plasmodium that enters the human body is:
questions.explanation: Sporozoites are the infective stage of Plasmodium that are injected into the human body by the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. They first infect liver cells before entering the erythrocytic cycle.

questions.question: Common cold is caused by:
questions.explanation: Common cold is caused by Rhinoviruses. It infects the nose and respiratory passage but not the lungs. The virus is transmitted through droplets from coughs or sneezes or through contaminated objects.

questions.question: Elephantiasis is caused by:
questions.explanation: Elephantiasis (filariasis) is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Wuchereria malayi. These filarial worms live in the lymphatic vessels and block lymph drainage, causing chronic inflammation and swelling of lower limbs.

questions.question: Which immunoglobulin is responsible for allergic reactions?
questions.explanation: IgE antibodies are responsible for allergic reactions. They are produced in response to allergens and bind to mast cells, causing the release of histamine and serotonin which lead to allergic symptoms.

questions.question: HIV attacks which type of cells in the human body?
questions.explanation: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) primarily attacks helper T-lymphocytes (CD4+ T cells), macrophages, and monocytes. The progressive decline in helper T cells leads to immunodeficiency.

questions.question: Which of the following is a protozoan disease?
questions.explanation: Amoebiasis is caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica. Ascariasis is a helminth disease, ringworm is a fungal disease, and typhoid is a bacterial disease.

questions.question: Ringworm in humans is caused by:
questions.explanation: Ringworm is caused by fungi belonging to genera Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton. Despite the name, it is not caused by a worm. It appears as dry, scaly lesions on skin, nails, and scalp.

questions.question: The__(A)__ cells in our body produce antibodies, while __(B)__ cells are responsible for cell-mediated immunity. Choose the correct pair:
questions.explanation: B-lymphocytes produce antibodies and are responsible for humoral immunity, while T-lymphocytes are responsible for cell-mediated immunity (CMI). Both are types of lymphocytes derived from bone marrow stem cells.

questions.question: Pneumonia is caused by which of the following organisms?
options: C) Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae
questions.explanation: Pneumonia is caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. It infects the alveoli of the lungs, filling them with fluid leading to breathing difficulty.

questions.question: Which substance released by mast cells is responsible for allergic symptoms such as sneezing and watery eyes?
questions.explanation: Histamine and serotonin are released from mast cells in response to allergens binding to IgE antibodies. Histamine causes vasodilation and increased mucus secretion, leading to symptoms like sneezing, watery eyes, and running nose.

questions.question: Conversion of proto-oncogenes to oncogenes leads to:
questions.explanation: Proto-oncogenes are normal genes that control cell growth and differentiation. When mutated or activated abnormally, they become oncogenes that lead to uncontrolled cell division and cancer.

questions.question: Which drug is obtained from the latex of Papaver somniferum?
questions.explanation: Morphine is an opioid drug obtained from the latex of the poppy plant Papaver somniferum. Other opioids derived from the same source include heroin (diacetylmorphine) and codeine.

questions.question: ELISA test is based on the principle of:
questions.explanation: ELISA (Enzyme Linked Immuno-Sorbent Assay) is based on the principle of antigen-antibody interaction. It is widely used for the detection of HIV infection and other diseases.

questions.question: The__(A)__ is an example of innate immunity barrier, while __(B)__ represents acquired immunity. Choose the correct option:
questions.explanation: Skin is a physical barrier that is part of innate (non-specific) immunity. Vaccination provides acquired (adaptive/specific) immunity by stimulating the immune system to produce memory cells against specific pathogens.

questions.question: The__(A)__ test is used for confirming AIDS after a positive ELISA test. Choose the correct option:
questions.explanation: Western blot is the confirmatory test for HIV/AIDS after an initial positive ELISA test. It detects specific HIV proteins and has higher specificity than ELISA.

questions.question: Metastasis is the property of:
options: C) Both benign and malignant tumors
questions.explanation: Metastasis is the property of malignant tumors (cancerous cells) to spread from the primary site to distant organs through blood and lymph. Benign tumors remain confined to their original location and do not show metastasis.

questions.question: Cannabinoids are obtained from:
questions.explanation: Cannabinoids (marijuana, hashish, charas, ganja) are obtained from the inflorescences of Cannabis sativa. They interact with cannabinoid receptors in the brain and affect cardiovascular system.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Innate immunity is non-specific and is present at birth.
Reason (R): Innate immunity includes barriers like skin, mucus, and antimicrobial substances like lysozyme in tears.
options: A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Innate immunity is indeed non-specific and present from birth. The reason correctly explains the assertion by listing the physical and chemical barriers (skin, mucus, lysozyme) that constitute innate immunity.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Secondary immune response is faster and stronger than the primary immune response.
Reason (R): Memory B and T cells generated during the primary response enable a rapid and heightened response upon subsequent exposure.
options: B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: The secondary (anamnestic) immune response is faster and more intense because memory cells formed during the first encounter with the antigen quickly proliferate and mount a stronger response on re-exposure.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): HIV is a retrovirus.
Reason (R): HIV has RNA as its genetic material and possesses the enzyme reverse transcriptase.
options: B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: HIV is classified as a retrovirus because it has RNA as its genetic material and uses the enzyme reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into DNA inside the host cell. This is the defining characteristic of retroviruses.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Colostrum is recommended for newborn infants.
Reason (R): Colostrum contains abundant IgA antibodies that provide passive immunity to the newborn.
options: C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Colostrum, the yellowish fluid produced by the mother during the initial days of lactation, contains IgA antibodies that protect the infant against various pathogens. This is a form of passive immunity.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Benign tumors are not life threatening.
Reason (R): Benign tumors do not show metastasis and remain confined to their site of origin.
options: B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Benign tumors are generally not life threatening because they do not exhibit metastasis. They remain confined to their original location, do not invade surrounding tissues, and can usually be surgically removed.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Smoking increases the risk of lung cancer.
Reason (R): Tobacco smoke contains carcinogenic chemicals like benzopyrene that cause mutations in lung cells.
options: B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Smoking is a major cause of lung cancer. Tobacco smoke contains over 4000 chemicals, many of which are carcinogenic. Benzopyrene and other polycyclic hydrocarbons damage DNA and activate proto-oncogenes.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Malaria causes recurrent bouts of fever at regular intervals.
Reason (R): The rupture of RBCs releasing merozoites and a toxic substance called haemozoin coincides with the episodes of fever.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: In malaria, the rupture of infected RBCs releases merozoites along with haemozoin (a toxic substance). This triggers the release of pyrogenic substances that cause the characteristic cyclic high fever with chills.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Vaccination is based on the principle of immunological memory.
Reason (R): On subsequent exposure to the same pathogen, the immune system mounts a weak and slow response.
options: D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: The assertion is true: vaccination works on the principle of immunological memory. However, the reason is false. On subsequent exposure, the immune system mounts a faster, stronger (not weak and slow) secondary immune response due to memory cells.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): AIDS patients suffer from many infections and cancers.
Reason (R): HIV destroys helper T-cells, leading to progressive weakening of the immune system.
options: B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: AIDS patients become susceptible to opportunistic infections (like Mycobacterium, Toxoplasma) and certain cancers because HIV progressively destroys helper T-cells (CD4+), which are essential for coordinating immune responses.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Interferons are produced by virus-infected cells.
Reason (R): Interferons protect non-infected cells from further viral attack.
options: A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. Virus-infected cells release interferons, and interferons do protect non-infected cells. However, the reason does not explain why virus-infected cells produce interferons (which is a defense mechanism), so R is not the correct explanation of A.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca and acts as a stimulant.
Reason (R): Cocaine interferes with the transport of the neurotransmitter dopamine.
options: C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Cocaine is obtained from the coca plant (Erythroxylum coca). It acts as a powerful stimulant because it interferes with the reuptake of dopamine, causing an accumulation of the neurotransmitter at the synapse, leading to a sense of euphoria.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Autoimmunity is the result of the immune system attacking self-cells.
Reason (R): Rheumatoid arthritis is an example of autoimmune disease.
options: A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. Autoimmunity occurs when the immune system fails to distinguish self from non-self and attacks the body's own tissues. Rheumatoid arthritis is indeed an autoimmune disease, but it is merely an example, not an explanation of the mechanism.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The sexual cycle of Plasmodium takes place inside the mosquito.
Reason (R): The mosquito is the definitive host of Plasmodium.
options: B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The sexual cycle (gametogony) of Plasmodium occurs inside the female Anopheles mosquito, making it the definitive host (the organism in which the parasite undergoes sexual reproduction). The reason correctly explains why the mosquito is called the definitive host.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Ascariasis is common in children.
Reason (R): Children are more prone to soil contamination and practice poor hygiene.
options: D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Ascariasis, caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, is common in children because they frequently play in soil contaminated with roundworm eggs and have poor hygiene habits, leading to oral ingestion of infective eggs.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is/are correct?
(i) Typhoid is caused by Salmonella typhi and diagnosed by Widal test.
(ii) Pneumonia infects the alveoli of the lungs.
(iii) Common cold is caused by Rhinoviruses and affects the lungs.
(iv) Malaria is caused by Plasmodium and transmitted by female Culex mosquito.
questions.explanation: Statement (i) is correct: typhoid is caused by Salmonella typhi and diagnosed by Widal test. Statement (ii) is correct: pneumonia infects the alveoli. Statement (iii) is wrong: common cold affects the nose and respiratory passage, not the lungs. Statement (iv) is wrong: malaria is transmitted by female Anopheles (not Culex) mosquito.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about HIV:
(i) HIV is an enveloped virus with two single-stranded RNA molecules.
(ii) It has reverse transcriptase enzyme.
(iii) HIV primarily infects cytotoxic T-cells.
(iv) It can be transmitted through sharing food.
How many of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i) and (ii) are correct. HIV is an enveloped retrovirus with two copies of ssRNA and reverse transcriptase. Statement (iii) is wrong: HIV primarily infects helper T-cells (CD4+), not cytotoxic T-cells. Statement (iv) is wrong: HIV is not transmitted through casual contact or sharing food.

questions.question:
Read the following statements and select the correct option:
(i) Active immunity is slow but has long-lasting memory.
(ii) Passive immunity provides immediate protection but is short-lived.
(iii) Vaccination provides passive immunity.
(iv) Mother's milk provides active immunity to the newborn.
questions.explanation: Statements (i) and (ii) are correct. Active immunity develops slowly after exposure to antigens but provides long-lasting protection with memory. Passive immunity provides immediate but short-lived protection. Statement (iii) is wrong: vaccination provides active immunity. Statement (iv) is wrong: mother's milk (colostrum with IgA) provides passive immunity.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about cancer is/are incorrect?
(i) Contact inhibition is shown by cancer cells.
(ii) Benign tumors show metastasis.
(iii) Oncogenes are genes that promote cell growth and division.
(iv) Tumor suppressor genes normally inhibit cell division.
questions.explanation: Statement (i) is incorrect: cancer cells lack contact inhibition, which is why they continue to divide uncontrollably. Statement (ii) is incorrect: benign tumors do NOT show metastasis; only malignant tumors do. Statements (iii) and (iv) are correct descriptions of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about drug abuse:
(i) Opioids bind to specific opioid receptors present in the central nervous system.
(ii) Cannabinoids are obtained from Erythroxylum coca.
(iii) Cocaine causes a sense of euphoria by interfering with dopamine transport.
(iv) Heroin (smack) is chemically diacetylmorphine.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (iii), and (iv) are correct. Opioids bind to opioid receptors in the CNS. Cocaine interferes with dopamine transport. Heroin is diacetylmorphine. Statement (ii) is wrong: cannabinoids are obtained from Cannabis sativa, not Erythroxylum coca (which yields cocaine).

questions.question:
How many of the following statements are correct?
(i) Ascaris lumbricoides is the causative organism of ascariasis.
(ii) Internal symptoms of ascariasis include fever, anaemia, and blockage of intestinal passage.
(iii) Amoebiasis is also called amoebic dysentery.
(iv) Entamoeba histolytica is transmitted by houseflies acting as mechanical carriers.
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct. Ascaris lumbricoides causes ascariasis with symptoms including fever, anaemia, and intestinal blockage. Amoebiasis (caused by Entamoeba histolytica) is also called amoebic dysentery. Houseflies serve as mechanical carriers that transmit the parasite from faeces to food.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the life cycle of Plasmodium is/are correct?
(i) The asexual cycle of Plasmodium occurs in the human body.
(ii) Sporozoites are formed inside the human liver.
(iii) Merozoites infect red blood cells.
(iv) Gametocytes are formed in the human body and fertilization occurs in the mosquito.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (iii), and (iv) are correct. The asexual cycle occurs in humans. Merozoites infect RBCs. Gametocytes form in the human body, and fertilization happens in the mosquito. Statement (ii) is wrong: sporozoites are formed in the mosquito's salivary glands, not the human liver. In the liver, sporozoites multiply to form merozoites.

questions.question:
Read the following statements:
(i) Morphine is an effective sedative and painkiller.
(ii) Smack (heroin) is obtained from the latex of Papaver somniferum.
(iii) LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is obtained from Cannabis sativa.
(iv) Barbiturates are commonly used sleeping pills.
Select the option with all correct statements:
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. Morphine is a potent sedative and painkiller. Heroin (smack) is derived from morphine obtained from Papaver somniferum. Barbiturates are commonly used sleeping pills. Statement (iii) is wrong: LSD is obtained from the fungus Claviceps purpurea, not Cannabis sativa.

questions.question:
How many of the following are transmitted by contaminated food and water?
(i) Typhoid
(ii) Amoebiasis
(iii) Ascariasis
(iv) Malaria
(v) Elephantiasis
questions.explanation: Typhoid (Salmonella typhi), amoebiasis (Entamoeba histolytica), and ascariasis (Ascaris eggs) are transmitted through contaminated food and water. Malaria is transmitted by mosquito bites (female Anopheles), and elephantiasis is also vector-borne (transmitted by mosquitoes).

questions.question:
Match the diseases in Column I with their causative organisms in Column II:
Column I: (P) Typhoid (Q) Pneumonia (R) Malaria (S) Ringworm
Column II: (i) Microsporum (ii) Plasmodium (iii) Salmonella typhi (iv) Streptococcus pneumoniae
questions.explanation: Typhoid is caused by Salmonella typhi (P-iii). Pneumonia is caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae (Q-iv). Malaria is caused by Plasmodium (R-ii). Ringworm is caused by Microsporum (S-i).

questions.question:
Match the drugs in Column I with their sources in Column II:
Column I: (P) Morphine (Q) Cocaine (R) Marijuana (S) LSD
Column II: (i) Cannabis sativa (ii) Erythroxylum coca (iii) Papaver somniferum (iv) Claviceps purpurea
questions.explanation: Morphine is obtained from Papaver somniferum (poppy plant). Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca (coca plant). Marijuana is obtained from Cannabis sativa (hemp plant). LSD is obtained from Claviceps purpurea (ergot fungus).

questions.question:
Match the type of immunity in Column I with its example in Column II:
Column I: (P) Active immunity (Q) Passive immunity (R) Innate immunity (S) Cell-mediated immunity
Column II: (i) Skin and mucous membranes (ii) Colostrum (iii) Vaccination (iv) T-lymphocytes
questions.explanation: Active immunity is achieved through vaccination (P-iii). Passive immunity is provided by colostrum containing ready-made antibodies (Q-ii). Innate immunity includes physical barriers like skin and mucous membranes (R-i). Cell-mediated immunity involves T-lymphocytes (S-iv).

questions.question:
Match the diagnostic tests in Column I with the diseases they detect in Column II:
Column I: (P) Widal test (Q) ELISA (R) Western blot (S) Biopsy
Column II: (i) Cancer confirmation (ii) Typhoid (iii) HIV screening (iv) HIV confirmation
questions.explanation: Widal test is used for diagnosing typhoid (P-ii). ELISA is the screening test for HIV (Q-iii). Western blot is the confirmatory test for HIV (R-iv). Biopsy involves tissue examination and is used for confirming cancer (S-i).

questions.question:
Match the diseases in Column I with their vectors/mode of transmission in Column II:
Column I: (P) Malaria (Q) Elephantiasis (R) Typhoid (S) Common cold
Column II: (i) Contaminated food and water (ii) Droplet infection (iii) Female Anopheles mosquito (iv) Female Culex mosquito
questions.explanation: Malaria is transmitted by female Anopheles mosquito (P-iii). Elephantiasis is transmitted by female Culex mosquito (Q-iv). Typhoid is transmitted through contaminated food and water (R-i). Common cold is transmitted through droplet infection (S-ii).

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II regarding cancer:
Column I: (P) Carcinoma (Q) Sarcoma (R) Lymphoma (S) Leukemia
Column II: (i) Cancer of blood cells (ii) Cancer of epithelial tissues (iii) Cancer of connective tissue (iv) Cancer of lymphatic tissue
questions.explanation: Carcinoma is cancer of epithelial tissues (P-ii). Sarcoma is cancer of connective tissues like bones and cartilage (Q-iii). Lymphoma is cancer of lymphatic tissue (R-iv). Leukemia is cancer of blood/blood-forming cells (S-i).

questions.question:
How many of the following are bacterial diseases?
(a) Typhoid (b) Pneumonia (c) Malaria (d) Common cold (e) Amoebiasis (f) Plague (g) Diphtheria (h) Ringworm
questions.explanation: The bacterial diseases in the list are: Typhoid (Salmonella typhi), Pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae), Plague (Yersinia pestis), and Diphtheria (Corynebacterium diphtheriae). Malaria is protozoan, common cold is viral, amoebiasis is protozoan, and ringworm is fungal.

questions.question:
How many of the following are components of innate immunity?
(a) Skin (b) Mucus in respiratory tract (c) Acid in stomach (d) Antibodies (e) Tears containing lysozyme (f) Interferons (g) Memory B-cells (h) Neutrophils
questions.explanation: Components of innate immunity: Skin (physical barrier), mucus in respiratory tract (physical barrier), acid in stomach (chemical barrier), tears containing lysozyme (chemical barrier), interferons (cytokine barrier), and neutrophils (cellular barrier). Antibodies and memory B-cells are components of acquired/adaptive immunity.

questions.question:
How many of the following are correct modes of HIV transmission?
(a) Sexual contact with infected person
(b) Transfusion of contaminated blood
(c) Sharing injection needles
(d) Sharing food with infected person
(e) From infected mother to child through placenta
(f) Mosquito bites
(g) Handshake with infected person
questions.explanation: The correct modes of HIV transmission are: (a) sexual contact, (b) contaminated blood transfusion, (c) sharing needles, and (e) mother to child through placenta. HIV is NOT transmitted by sharing food, mosquito bites, or handshakes.

questions.question:
Arrange the following events of the Plasmodium life cycle in the human body in the correct sequence:
(i) Merozoites released into blood
(ii) Sporozoites enter liver cells
(iii) Rupture of RBCs releases haemozoin
(iv) Merozoites attack red blood cells
(v) Sporozoites injected by mosquito bite
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Sporozoites are injected by mosquito bite (v)  enter liver cells and multiply (ii)  merozoites are released into blood (i)  merozoites attack RBCs (iv)  rupture of RBCs releases haemozoin causing fever (iii).

questions.question:
Arrange the following events in the replication of HIV in the correct order:
(i) Integration of viral DNA into host genome
(ii) Reverse transcription of viral RNA to DNA
(iii) Binding of HIV to CD4 receptor on helper T-cell
(iv) Production of new virus particles
(v) Release of viral RNA into host cell
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of HIV replication: HIV binds to CD4 receptor on helper T-cell (iii)  viral RNA is released into host cell (v)  reverse transcriptase converts viral RNA to DNA (ii)  viral DNA integrates into host genome (i)  new virus particles are produced and released (iv).

questions.question:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence of an allergic reaction:
(i) Symptoms like sneezing, watery eyes appear
(ii) Allergen enters the body
(iii) IgE antibodies bind to mast cells
(iv) Histamine and serotonin are released
(v) B-cells produce IgE antibodies
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of allergic reaction: Allergen enters the body (ii)  B-cells produce IgE antibodies (v)  IgE antibodies bind to mast cells (iii)  mast cells release histamine and serotonin (iv)  allergic symptoms like sneezing and watery eyes appear (i).

questions.question: Which Plasmodium species is responsible for the most serious (malignant) form of malaria?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium falciparum causes the most severe and potentially fatal form of malaria known as malignant malaria. It can cause cerebral malaria and has the highest mortality rate among all Plasmodium species.

questions.question: Salmonella typhi first reaches which organ after ingestion through contaminated food?
questions.explanation: Salmonella typhi enters the body through contaminated food and water. It first reaches the small intestine through the intestinal wall and then migrates to other organs like the liver and spleen through the bloodstream.

questions.question: Which type of cells are responsible for graft rejection in organ transplantation?
questions.explanation: T-lymphocytes are responsible for cell-mediated immunity, which plays a key role in graft rejection. They recognize foreign MHC markers on the transplanted tissue and mount an immune response to destroy the graft.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a symptom of typhoid?
options: C) Skin lesions with dry scaly patches
D) Intestinal perforation in severe cases
questions.explanation: Skin lesions with dry scaly patches are symptoms of ringworm (a fungal infection), not typhoid. Typhoid symptoms include sustained high fever, weakness, stomach pain, constipation, headache, and in severe cases, intestinal perforation.

questions.question: In the life cycle of Plasmodium, the phase where the parasite multiplies within the liver cells is called:
questions.explanation: Pre-erythrocytic (exo-erythrocytic) schizogony is the phase where sporozoites multiply asexually within liver cells (hepatocytes) to form merozoites before they enter red blood cells. Erythrocytic schizogony occurs in RBCs.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is caused by a helminth that lives in the lymphatic vessels?
questions.explanation: Elephantiasis (filariasis) is caused by Wuchereria species (filarial worms) that live in the lymphatic vessels of the lower limbs. They block lymph drainage, causing chronic inflammation and swelling of limbs and genital organs.

questions.question: Which protein on the surface of HIV helps in attaching to the host cell receptor?
questions.explanation: The glycoprotein gp120 on the surface of HIV binds to the CD4 receptor on the surface of helper T-lymphocytes, macrophages, and monocytes. This is the first step of HIV infection.

questions.question: Tumor suppressor genes, when inactivated, can lead to:
questions.explanation: Tumor suppressor genes (like p53 and Rb) normally inhibit cell division and promote apoptosis. When these genes are inactivated or mutated, cells lose their growth control mechanisms, leading to uncontrolled cell division and cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following effects is NOT associated with alcohol abuse?
questions.explanation: Increased dopamine at synapses is an effect of cocaine, not alcohol. Alcohol abuse leads to liver cirrhosis (damage to liver cells), damage to the nervous system, and can also affect kidneys. Alcohol acts as a depressant on the central nervous system.

questions.question: Antibodies are produced by:
questions.explanation: Antibodies are produced by plasma cells, which are activated B-lymphocytes. When B-cells encounter an antigen, they differentiate into plasma cells that secrete large quantities of antibodies specific to that antigen.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Typhoid carrier can spread the disease even without showing symptoms.
Reason (R): Salmonella typhi can survive in the gall bladder of the carrier and be shed through stool.
options: A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Typhoid carriers harbour Salmonella typhi in their gall bladder without showing symptoms. The bacteria are shed through stool, contaminating food and water, and thus spreading the disease to others.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about antibodies:
(i) Antibodies are also called immunoglobulins.
(ii) Each antibody has four polypeptide chains - two heavy and two light chains.
(iii) IgG can cross the placenta and provides immunity to the fetus.
(iv) IgM is the first antibody produced during primary immune response.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation: All statements are correct. Antibodies are immunoglobulins with two heavy and two light polypeptide chains forming a Y-shape. IgG is the only antibody that crosses the placenta. IgM is the first antibody produced in the primary immune response.

questions.question:
How many of the following statements about tobacco are correct?
(i) Nicotine stimulates the adrenal gland to release adrenaline and noradrenaline.
(ii) Smoking increases the carbon monoxide content in blood, reducing oxygen-carrying capacity.
(iii) Tobacco chewing causes oral cancer.
(iv) Smoking has no effect on the cardiovascular system.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Nicotine stimulates the adrenal gland to release adrenaline and noradrenaline, increasing blood pressure and heart rate. Smoking increases CO in blood. Tobacco chewing causes oral cancer. Statement (iv) is wrong: smoking severely affects the cardiovascular system.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about ringworm is/are correct?
(i) It is caused by fungi of genera Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton.
(ii) It appears as dry, scaly lesions on skin, nails, and scalp.
(iii) Ringworm is highly contagious and spreads through towels, combs, or soil.
(iv) It is an internal parasitic infection affecting the intestine.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Ringworm is caused by dermatophyte fungi and produces dry, scaly lesions. It spreads through contact with infected persons or contaminated objects. Statement (iv) is wrong: ringworm is a superficial skin infection, not an intestinal infection.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
(i) Heroin binds to opioid receptors in the CNS and gastrointestinal tract.
(ii) Heroin is a depressant that slows down body functions.
(iii) Withdrawal symptoms of heroin include anxiety, sweating, and nausea.
(iv) Heroin increases alertness and improves cognitive function.
How many of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Heroin (diacetylmorphine) binds to opioid receptors in the CNS and GI tract. It is a depressant that slows body functions. Withdrawal produces anxiety, sweating, nausea, and muscular cramps. Statement (iv) is wrong: heroin is a depressant, not a stimulant.

questions.question:
Match the diseases in Column I with their affected organs in Column II:
Column I: (P) Typhoid (Q) Pneumonia (R) Amoebiasis (S) Ascariasis
Column II: (i) Lungs (ii) Large intestine (iii) Small intestine (iv) Intestine (internal organs)
questions.explanation: Typhoid initially affects the small intestine (P-iii). Pneumonia affects the lungs/alveoli (Q-i). Amoebiasis affects the large intestine causing dysentery (R-ii). Ascariasis affects the intestine and can migrate to internal organs (S-iv).

questions.question:
Match the type of drug in Column I with its effect on the body in Column II:
Column I: (P) Opioids (Q) Cannabinoids (R) Cocaine (S) Barbiturates
Column II: (i) CNS stimulant, euphoria (ii) Sedation and pain relief (iii) Affects cardiovascular system (iv) Depressant, induces sleep
questions.explanation: Opioids cause sedation and pain relief (P-ii). Cannabinoids affect the cardiovascular system (Q-iii). Cocaine is a CNS stimulant producing euphoria (R-i). Barbiturates are depressants that induce sleep (S-iv).

questions.question:
Match the immune cells in Column I with their functions in Column II:
Column I: (P) B-lymphocytes (Q) Helper T-cells (R) Cytotoxic T-cells (S) Natural Killer cells
Column II: (i) Kill virus-infected cells directly (ii) Produce antibodies (iii) Help activate B-cells and other immune cells (iv) Part of innate immunity, destroy tumor cells
questions.explanation: B-lymphocytes produce antibodies (P-ii). Helper T-cells help activate other immune cells including B-cells (Q-iii). Cytotoxic T-cells directly kill virus-infected and cancer cells (R-i). Natural Killer cells are part of innate immunity and destroy tumor cells (S-iv).

questions.question:
Match the Plasmodium stages in Column I with their location in Column II:
Column I: (P) Sporozoites (Q) Merozoites in liver (R) Gametocytes (S) Ookinete
Column II: (i) Human RBCs (ii) Mosquito gut wall (iii) Human liver cells (iv) Mosquito salivary glands
questions.explanation: Sporozoites are found in the mosquito's salivary glands before being injected into humans (P-iv). Merozoites multiply in liver cells (hepatocytes) (Q-iii). Gametocytes are formed in human RBCs (R-i). Ookinete penetrates the mosquito gut wall to form oocysts (S-ii).

questions.question:
Match the autoimmune diseases in Column I with the tissues affected in Column II:
Column I: (P) Rheumatoid arthritis (Q) Type I diabetes (R) Multiple sclerosis (S) Graves' disease
Column II: (i) Beta cells of pancreas (ii) Joints (iii) Myelin sheath of nerves (iv) Thyroid gland
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis affects joints (P-ii). Type I diabetes involves autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells (Q-i). Multiple sclerosis attacks the myelin sheath of nerves (R-iii). Graves' disease affects the thyroid gland (S-iv).

questions.question:
Match the HIV structural components in Column I with their descriptions in Column II:
Column I: (P) gp120 (Q) Reverse transcriptase (R) Capsid (p24) (S) RNA genome
Column II: (i) Converts viral RNA to DNA (ii) Two copies of single-stranded RNA (iii) Surface glycoprotein that binds CD4 (iv) Protein coat surrounding viral genome
questions.explanation: gp120 is the surface glycoprotein that binds to the CD4 receptor (P-iii). Reverse transcriptase is the enzyme that converts viral RNA to DNA (Q-i). The capsid made of p24 protein surrounds the viral genome (R-iv). HIV has two copies of single-stranded RNA as its genome (S-ii).

questions.question:
How many of the following are features of malignant tumors?
(a) Uncontrolled cell growth
(b) Metastasis
(c) Contact inhibition
(d) Invasion of surrounding tissues
(e) Loss of cell differentiation
(f) Encapsulated growth
questions.explanation: Features of malignant tumors: uncontrolled cell growth (a), metastasis (b), invasion of surrounding tissues (d), and loss of cell differentiation (e). Contact inhibition (c) is a property of NORMAL cells, not malignant tumors. Encapsulated growth (f) is a feature of BENIGN tumors.

questions.question:
How many of the following are physical barriers of innate immunity?
(a) Skin
(b) Mucus lining of respiratory tract
(c) Acid in stomach
(d) Tears
(e) Saliva
(f) Cilia in nasal passage
questions.explanation: Physical barriers of innate immunity include: skin (a), mucus lining of respiratory tract (b), and cilia in nasal passage (f). Acid in stomach (c), tears (d), and saliva (e) contain antimicrobial chemicals and are classified as chemical/physiological barriers rather than physical barriers.

questions.question:
How many of the following diseases are caused by protozoans?
(a) Malaria (b) Amoebiasis (c) Sleeping sickness (d) Kala-azar (e) Ringworm (f) Ascariasis (g) Typhoid (h) Leishmaniasis
questions.explanation: Protozoan diseases in the list: Malaria (Plasmodium), Amoebiasis (Entamoeba histolytica), Sleeping sickness (Trypanosoma), Kala-azar (Leishmania donovani), and Leishmaniasis (Leishmania). Ringworm is fungal, ascariasis is helminthic, and typhoid is bacterial.

questions.question:
How many of the following are carcinogens (cancer-causing agents)?
(a) Ionizing radiation (b) UV radiation (c) Tobacco smoke chemicals (d) Certain viruses (e) Vitamin C (f) Physical irritants like asbestos
questions.explanation: Carcinogens include: ionizing radiation (a), UV radiation (b), tobacco smoke chemicals like benzopyrene (c), certain oncogenic viruses (d), and physical irritants like asbestos (f). Vitamin C (e) is an antioxidant and is NOT a carcinogen.

questions.question:
Arrange the following events in the correct sequence during a humoral immune response:
(i) Plasma cells secrete antibodies
(ii) Antigen is recognized by B-cell
(iii) Antibodies bind to antigen and neutralize it
(iv) B-cell differentiates into plasma cells and memory cells
(v) Antigen is presented by antigen-presenting cell
questions.explanation: The correct sequence: Antigen is presented by APC (v)  antigen is recognized by B-cell (ii)  B-cell differentiates into plasma cells and memory cells (iv)  plasma cells secrete antibodies (i)  antibodies bind to antigen and neutralize it (iii).

questions.question:
Arrange the following stages of cancer progression in the correct order:
(i) Metastasis to distant organs
(ii) Normal cell undergoes mutation
(iii) Formation of primary tumor
(iv) Tumor cells invade surrounding tissues
(v) Cancer cells enter blood/lymph vessels
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of cancer progression: Normal cell undergoes mutation (ii)  uncontrolled division leads to formation of primary tumor (iii)  tumor cells invade surrounding tissues (iv)  cancer cells enter blood/lymph vessels (v)  metastasis to distant organs (i).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic symptom of AIDS?
questions.explanation: High blood pressure is not a characteristic symptom of AIDS. AIDS symptoms include recurring fever, diarrhoea, weight loss, and susceptibility to opportunistic infections like Toxoplasma, Mycobacterium, and certain cancers due to progressive immune system failure.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the difference between active and passive immunity?
options: A) Active immunity is immediate; passive immunity takes time to develop
B) Active immunity involves memory cells; passive immunity does not
C) Passive immunity is long-lasting; active immunity is temporary
D) Both types involve memory cell formation
questions.explanation: Active immunity involves the body producing its own antibodies and memory cells in response to antigens (either through infection or vaccination), making it long-lasting. Passive immunity involves receiving ready-made antibodies (e.g., from mother) without forming memory cells, making it short-lived.

questions.question: Which of the following is used in the treatment of cancer?
options: C) Radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and surgery
questions.explanation: Cancer is treated using a combination of approaches including surgery (removal of tumor), radiation therapy (using ionizing radiation to kill cancer cells), chemotherapy (using cytotoxic drugs), and immunotherapy. Antibiotics treat bacterial infections, not cancer.

questions.question: The genetic material of HIV is:
questions.explanation: HIV contains two copies of single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) as its genetic material. Being a retrovirus, HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its ssRNA into DNA, which then integrates into the host cell genome.

questions.question: Amoebiasis is transmitted through:
options: C) Contaminated food and water; houseflies as mechanical carriers
questions.explanation: Amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery) caused by Entamoeba histolytica is transmitted through contaminated food and water. Houseflies serve as mechanical carriers, transmitting the parasite from faeces of infected persons to food and food products.

questions.question: The toxic substance released upon rupture of RBCs in malaria is:
questions.explanation: When Plasmodium merozoites multiply inside RBCs and rupture them, they release a toxic substance called haemozoin. This is responsible for the recurring high fever and chills characteristic of malaria.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Elephantiasis causes massive swelling of the lower limbs.
Reason (R): The filarial worms Wuchereria bancrofti block the lymphatic drainage of the affected areas.
options: A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The filarial worms live in the lymphatic vessels and block normal lymph drainage, causing chronic inflammation of lymphatic organs. This leads to accumulation of lymph fluid and massive swelling, particularly in the lower limbs and genital organs.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the human immune system is/are correct?
(i) T-lymphocytes mature in the thymus gland.
(ii) B-lymphocytes mature in the bone marrow.
(iii) Both T and B cells originate from stem cells in the liver.
(iv) The spleen acts as a secondary lymphoid organ.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. T-lymphocytes mature in the thymus, B-lymphocytes mature in the bone marrow, and the spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ. Statement (iii) is wrong: both T and B cells originate from stem cells in the bone marrow (not the liver).

questions.question:
Match the immunoglobulins in Column I with their properties in Column II:
Column I: (P) IgA (Q) IgE (R) IgG (S) IgM
Column II: (i) Found in colostrum and mucosal secretions (ii) Responsible for allergic reactions (iii) Most abundant antibody in blood (iv) First antibody in primary immune response
questions.explanation: IgA is found in colostrum and mucosal secretions (P-i). IgE is responsible for allergic reactions by binding to mast cells (Q-ii). IgG is the most abundant antibody in blood and crosses the placenta (R-iii). IgM is the first antibody produced during primary immune response and is the largest immunoglobulin (S-iv).

questions.question:
How many of the following are vector-borne diseases?
(a) Malaria (b) Typhoid (c) Elephantiasis (d) Dengue (e) Pneumonia (f) Sleeping sickness (g) Amoebiasis
questions.explanation: Vector-borne diseases: Malaria (female Anopheles mosquito), Elephantiasis (female Culex mosquito), Dengue (Aedes mosquito), and Sleeping sickness (Tsetse fly). Typhoid and amoebiasis are waterborne, and pneumonia is airborne.

questions.question:
Arrange the following stages of drug addiction in the correct order:
(i) Tolerance develops requiring higher doses
(ii) Experimental or first-time use due to peer pressure
(iii) Physical and psychological dependence
(iv) Regular use
(v) Withdrawal symptoms appear on stopping
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of drug addiction: Experimental use due to peer pressure (ii)  regular use (iv)  tolerance develops requiring higher doses (i)  physical and psychological dependence (iii)  withdrawal symptoms on stopping (v).

questions.question:
Arrange the following events in the correct sequence during typhoid pathogenesis:
(i) Bacteria multiply in the intestinal wall
(ii) Ingestion of contaminated food/water
(iii) Sustained high fever (104°F)
(iv) Bacteria enter bloodstream
(v) Bacteria reach small intestine
questions.explanation: The correct sequence: Ingestion of contaminated food/water (ii)  bacteria reach the small intestine (v)  bacteria multiply in the intestinal wall (i)  bacteria enter the bloodstream (iv)  sustained high fever and other systemic symptoms (iii).

questions.question: Alpha interferon is used in the treatment of which disease?
questions.explanation: Alpha interferon is one of the biological response modifiers used in the treatment of cancer. Interferons activate the immune system and help the body fight cancer cells. They are used in immunotherapy of certain cancers.

questions.question: Which of the following organs is NOT a primary lymphoid organ?
options: D) Both A and B are primary lymphoid organs
questions.explanation: The spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ, not a primary one. Primary lymphoid organs are bone marrow and thymus, where immature lymphocytes differentiate into mature lymphocytes. Secondary lymphoid organs (spleen, lymph nodes, tonsils, Peyer's patches, MALT) are where lymphocytes interact with antigens.

questions.question: The larvae of Ascaris undergo migration through the body. This process is called:
questions.explanation: In ascariasis, the larvae of Ascaris undergo migration through the body. After hatching in the intestine, larvae penetrate the intestinal wall, travel through blood to the lungs, and return to the intestine. This larval migration causes symptoms like internal bleeding, muscular pain, fever, and anaemia.

questions.question: Which of the following viruses can cause cancer?
questions.explanation: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is an oncogenic virus that can cause cervical cancer. Other cancer-causing viruses include Hepatitis B and C (liver cancer), Epstein-Barr virus (Burkitt's lymphoma), and HTLV-1 (T-cell leukemia). These are biological carcinogens.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about drug dependence:
(i) Psychological dependence is the perceived need of a drug for normal functioning.
(ii) Physical dependence manifests as withdrawal symptoms.
(iii) Tolerance means the body needs progressively lower doses for the same effect.
(iv) Drug dependence can lead to social and health problems.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. Psychological dependence is the perceived need for a drug. Physical dependence shows as withdrawal symptoms. Drug abuse causes social and health problems. Statement (iii) is wrong: tolerance means the body needs progressively HIGHER (not lower) doses for the same effect.

questions.question:
Match the lymphoid organs in Column I with their types in Column II:
Column I: (P) Thymus (Q) Spleen (R) Bone marrow (S) Peyer's patches
Column II: (i) Primary lymphoid organ (ii) Secondary lymphoid organ
questions.explanation: Thymus (P-i) and bone marrow (R-i) are primary lymphoid organs where lymphocytes mature. Spleen (Q-ii) and Peyer's patches (S-ii) are secondary lymphoid organs where lymphocytes encounter antigens and mount immune responses.
